Disease and History

This medical historian presents a broad overview with attention to social, cultural, and economic results of major events and is highly critical of the role of the Church in its hindering advancement of medical knowledge in the medieval world

note: Suffers from oversimplification that sometimes distorts factual accuracy.
title: When Plague Strikes: The Black Death, Smallpox, AIDS
Written for young readers, it presents the Black Death in a wide context of human diseases past and present
Man and Microbes: Disease and Plagues in History and Modern Times
Provides broad context for study of human disease of many kinds
Plague, Pox and Pestilence: Disease in History
Series of well-illustrated essays on epidemics of different diseases from ancient to modern times. Contains brief but useful overview of the Black Death by Ann Carmichael
Plagues and Peoples
Classic study of man and disease from a world historical perspective. McNeill employs much conjecture for early periods, but he is on good ground for the Second Pandemic
Plagues: Their Origin, History, and Future
Examines many types of disease; contains a chapter on recent biological and ecological research and its implications
Annotated Bibliography Zinsser, Hans. Rats, Lice and History
Though dated and often irreverent, this overview of disease and science in history is worth reading for a look at its generation’s view of the Black Death, its causes, and its consequences
From the Brink of the Apocalypse: Crisis and Recovery in Late Medieval England
Aberth presents an overview of war, famine, and the Plague in the fourteenth and fifteenth centuries and the effects they had on English society
Plague in the Late Medieval Nordic Countries: Epidemiological Studies
Detailed study of evidence for the Plague and its effects in Scandinavian countries that concludes that despite the climate, rat-borne bubonic plague was the primary culprit
The Politics of Cleanliness in Northern Renaissance Italy
Links Florentine humanists’ interest in the city’s cleanliness with conceptions of the role of filth in the Plague
The Black Death in English Towns
English urban responses to the Plague were usually carried out by individuals and churchmen rather than civic governments
In the Wake of the Plague: The Black Death and the World It Made
Sometimes quirky series of case studies of how the Black Death affected people, relating them to larger social, political, and economic trends and issues of the period
Plague and the Poor in Renaissance Florence
Tightly focused study of Plague deaths in Florence, legislation and institutional changes prompted by them, and the ways these created effective social control of the Florentine poor
The Black Death
Aimed at a young adult audience; contains discussion of life at the time as it related to the Plague and its effects. With black and white illustrations

note: on the Black Death. Certainly dated on medical aspects of the disease, but contains much of value on the effects.
title: A History of Epidemics in Britain
Updated edition of 1891 overview of epidemic history
The Black Death in the Middle East

Remains the only book in English specifically on the late medieval Plague in the Islamic world. Dols deals with the spread, impacts, and influences of the epidemic both broadly and with a significant level of detail
Life During the Black Death
Aimed at a young adult audience; contains discussion of life at the time as it related to the Plague and its effects

container-title: Journal of the History of Biology
title: Black Death and the Silver Lining: Meaning, Continuity, and Revolutionary Change in Histories of Medieval Plague
Focuses on modern interpretations of the effects of Black Death and how these are influenced by modern culture
The Black Death: Natural and Human Disaster in Medieval Europe
Takes an “ecological approach” to the Black Death and its recurrences, considering the 300-year Plague era as an “environmental crisis” with wide-ranging effects for Europe’s population
The Black Death and the Transformation of the West

Consists of three lectures given at the University of Maine in 1985, published posthumously with notes and an introduction. A broad, critical overview of the Plague is followed by brief studies of economic effects and changes in culture
A History of the Black Death in Ireland
Study of the impact of the Black Death on Gaelic-Irish and Anglo-Irish society, economy, government, and Church that is well informed by recent scholarship
The Black Death and the History of Plagues, 1345–1730

Well-illustrated overview of medieval plagues and modern diseases—including HIV-AIDS, BSE, and smallpox—with emphasis on the commonality of human responses to epidemic disease and the importance of the precedents of the fourteenth century
The Black Death
Collection of extended excerpts from eleven major modern scholars as well as short translations otherwise found in Horrox, The Black Death, which is listed in this bibliography

note: reprinted in abridged form
dance mania, and children’s pilgrimages. Heavily reliant on primary sources, but poorly documented.
title: The Black Death: A Chronicle of the Plague
Descriptive overview of major aspects of the Plague and its effects and lesser aspects such as “erotic elements

container-title: Bulletin of the History of Medicine
note: This spawned an interesting response from Michael Dols and a counter from Norris, both of which appeared in the same journal 52 (1978): 112–20.
title: East or West? The Geographic Origin of the Black Death

Moves the point of origin of the Black Death from generally accepted China or central Asia to southern Russia, claiming that Asia received the Plague through India and Burma, independently of the western outbreak
The Black Death in England
Collection of articles on social, political, religious, and architectural history of the Plague in England, especially in the fourteenth century
King Death: The Black Death and Its Aftermath in Late-medieval England
Well-illustrated book that combines social and architectural history of late fourteenth and fifteenth century England as affected by the continuing waves of the Plague

note: Reasons that despite specific documentary evidence, the Black Death played major role in transformations of the western Mongol peoples.
title: Preliminary Remarks on the Role of Disease in the History of the Golden Horde
History of Bubonic Plague in the British Isles
Important treatment of Black Death in England in context of other epidemics that challenges the high death rates claimed by contemporary writers on the basis of the epidemiology of bubonic plague
Plague in Iceland
Reviews chronicle evidence of pneumonic plague in Iceland in the fifteenth century

container-title: Papers of the Eleventh Annual Conference of the Center for Medieval and Early Renaissance Studies
title: The Black Death: The Impact of the Fourteenth-century Plague
Contains seven papers on art, literature, economics, Islamic religious law, and eschatology
The Black Death
The standard history of the European Black Death in English, covering a wide range of related topics

note: Takes rats out of the picture of the Black Death, demonstrating that their role in spreading it was neither evident nor necessary.
title: The Scarcity of Rats and the Black Death: An Ecological History
Immunity as a Factor in the Epidemiology of Medieval Plague

Explores the role of natural and acquired immunity in animals and humans in the Plague’s rise, demographic impacts, and eventual disappearance. Pays special attention to the role of iron in the medieval diet and the patterns of who in society had the highest mortality

container-title: Bulletin of the History of Medicine
title: The Interhuman Transmission of Medieval Plague
Argues against the roles of the rat flea and rat in spreading the Plague, finding the human flea to be the more likely vector
More Cunning than Man: A Complete History of the Rat and Its Role in Human Civilization

container-title: Useful but traditional section on the Black Death; better on the nature and habits of rats
title: Broad and somewhat breezy treatment of the ways in which rats and people have intersected in history
Plague without Rats: The Case of Fifteenth-century Iceland
Argues against the rat’s necessity in spreading plague, conjecturing that Iceland’s epidemics were pneumonic, perhaps caused by a more virulent strain of the bacillus
Evolution of Plague Virulence
Brief article presents the theory that a mild strain of Y. pestis was present in enzootic phases of the Plague, but “point mutations” created supervirulent strains responsible for epidemics
Plague: A Story of Science, Rivalry, Scientific Breakthrough and the Scourge that Won’t Go Away

Written with the 204 Annotated Bibliography verve of a novel, Plague recounts in detail the rivalry in the 1890s between Kitasato and Yersin for the right to claim discovery of the cause of bubonic plague

container-title: Antiquity: A Quarterly Review of Archaeology
note: Archeological evidence for presence of R. rattus in Roman and Anglo-Saxon Britain.
title: Rattus rattus: The Introduction of the Black Rat into Britain

container-title: Proceedings of the National Academy of Science
note: Report of experiments with tooth pulp from Plague victims that supports the contention that Y. pestis was the cause of the Black Death.
title: Molecular Identification of ‘Suicide PCR’ of Yersinia pestis as the Agent of the Black Death

container-title: Serta devota in memoriam Guillelmi Lourdaux, II: Cultura mediaevalis (Mediaevalia Lovaniensia, Studia 21
title: Was the Black Death (1348–49) a Real Plague Epidemic? England as a Case-study
Questions the “classical theory” of rats-fleas-man (bubonic plague) for the 1340s and extent of population loss in England, based on reading of quoted original sources

container-title: Challenges dominant views of nature and effects of Black Death; briefer treatment of argument presented in the following book
title: The Black Death: End of a Paradigm
The Black Death Transformed: Disease and Culture in Early Renaissance Europe
Intriguingly revisionist view of what disease the pestilence really was and of confidence in medical knowledge; based on very wide reading of original sources
Biology of Plagues: Evidence from Historical Populations
Zoologist and demographer carefully outline patterns of Black Death, especially in England, and conclude that it was an outbreak of a hemorrhagic virus like Ebola
The Black Death: A Biological Reappraisal
Carefully constructed analysis of the Plague in England as described by contemporaries rejects bubonic plague in favor of anthrax as main cause of death

container-title: Maladies et societe (XIIe–XVIIIe siecles). Actes du Colloque de Bielefeld
title: The Black Death in England: An Epidemiological Dilemma

Argues against the Black Death of 1348 being bubonic plague, seeing the contrasting patterns of seasonality, incubation, and transmission of the medieval disease and modern bubonic plague as too great to ignore or explain away. Twigg sees anthrax as a reasonable alternative explanation

note: Short narrative of Jewish physician who was expelled in 1492 and landed in Istanbul.
title: Between East and West: A Jewish Doctor from Spain
Contagion Theory and Contagion Practice in Fifteenthcentury Milan
Shows how medical theory that denied the possibility of contagion conflicted with common observation of contagion and the communal action based upon it

container-title: Science and Technology in Medieval Society
note: Study of three generations of Montpellier-trained physician-authors reveals evolution away from reliance on traditional authorities and more reliance on one’s own experience and observation.
title: Fevers, Poisons and Apostemes: Authority and Experience in Montpellier Plague Treatises

container-title: The Medieval City: Essays In Honor of Robert S. Lopez
title: A Plague Doctor
Brief article follows the career of Dr. Ventura, communal physician of Pavia, comparing matters such as duties and salary to those of other communal Plague physicians

note: See his Chapter 6 on the Black Death.
title: Canonical Medicine: Gentile da Foligno and Scholasticism
Extended discussion of Gentile’s relation to and use of scholastic medicine, especially as found in his commentary on Avicenna’s Canon
Practical Medicine from Salerno to the Black Death
Contains articles on medical astrology, Jewish medical Plague tracts, the Milanese government’s Plague policies, and university physicians’ Plague tracts
The Black Death in Florence: Medical and Communal Responses

Presenting a counter-case to Carmichael’s Milan, Henderson contends that Florentine medical theory accepted contagion as possible and that communal responses reflected both popular and professional views

editor.literal: edited by Danielle Jacquart, Essay XIII

note: Concludes that little had changed in medical theory or practice for a century after the Black Death.
title: Theory, Everyday Practice, and Three Fifteenth-century Physicians.” In La Science medicale occidentale entre deux renaissances (XIIe s.–XVe s
The Teaching of Astronomy at the Medieval University of Paris
Links the medieval study of medicine with that of astronomy and astrology

container-title: Bottoms Up!: A Pathologist’s Essays on Medicine and the Humanities
note: Ill-titled article outlines life and views on contagion of the Andalusian physician and bureaucrat.
title: The Plague at Granada 1348–1349: Ibn Al-Khatib and Ideas of Contagion

container-title: The Church and Healing (Studies in Church History
Studies the balance of religious and medical responses, especially in Italian cities
title: The Church, Leprosy and Plague

container-title: Proceedings of the Royal Society of Medicine (History of Medicine
title: The Plague Tractates
Despite its age, provides very useful summaries of content of the major medical tracts by fourteenth-century physicians

container-title: Revue belge de philologie et d’histoire/Belgisch Annotated Bibliography
title: The Social and Economic Effects of Plague in the Low Countries: 1349–1500
Tijdschrift voor Filologie en Geschiedenis 58
Argues against common perception that the Low Countries suffered lightly in Black Death, and explores patterns and impacts of the Plague in late fourteenth and fifteenth centuries
The Jacquerie
Concludes that this French uprising of 1358 was conducted not by peasants, but by a slightly higher class of rural folk who were reacting to social trends that were accelerated by the Black Death
The Social and Economic Background to the Rural Revolt of 1381

Explores the causes of and participants in the so-called Peasants’ Revolt of 1381, noting the role of village elites and their grievances against lords who had become harsher masters since the Black Death
The Black Death of 1348 in Perpignan
Focusing on notarial evidence, Emery concludes that the Plague toll was high and economic effects very negative but that there was little breakdown in the social order

note: Close study of Episcopal records for deaths among priests.
title: The Effects and Extent of the Black Death of 1348: New Evidence for Clerical Mortality in Barcelona
Living and Dying in England, 1100–1540
A close study of the monastic community of Westminster Abbey, including medical care and the effects of the Black Death on the abbey’s population
Plague, Population and the English Economy, 1348–1530
Brief but detailed study of the long-term population decline of England that blames the Plague recurrences for most of the continued depression

container-title: Study of fiscal effects of the fall in population and revenue on the French Royal government
title: The Black Death and Royal Taxation in France, 1347–1351

container-title: Examines vitalization of Russian cities as rural peasants move in during 1350s
title: The Black Death in Russia: Its Effects upon Urban Labor

note: Highlights problems of using cathedral records of tenants as demographic source for Plague toll. Megson, Barbara E. “Mortality among London Citizens in the Black Death.”
title: Plague and the Russian Countryside: Monastic Estates in the Late Fourteenth and Fifteenth Centuries
Traces effects on rural labor force of the Plague’s depopulation
The Population of Europe: A History
In his Chapter 4 demographer Livi Bacci discusses the roles of diseases of many kinds in early modern Europe, centering on the Plague and its effects
The Black Death in County Durham
Brief outline of demographic effects of first epidemic
A Rural Society after the Black Death: Essex, 1350–1525
Focuses on marriage, migration, employment, social unrest, and religious nonconformity as affected by the pestilence and other historical factors
Accommodating Plague in Medieval Marseille
Sketches a range of issues from notarial documents: immigration, marriage, debt, property transfer, legal services
Demographic Developments in Rural England, 1300–1348
A good place to start in untangling demographic effects of the Plague from demographic patterns already at work in pre-Plague England

container-title: The Black Death: The Impact of the Fourteenth-century Plague
publisher: Medieval and Renaissance Texts and Studies
title: The Plague as Key to Meaning in Boccaccio’s Decameron

Studies the moralistic lessons Boccaccio provides his readers, most important of which is the precariousness of life as proven in the realistic treatment of the Plague in the framing elements of the collection
The Impact of the Black Death upon Sienese Government Annotated Bibliography 209

note: Links the Plague to personal and family concerns in art patronage of early Renaissance.
title: The Cult of Remembrance and the Black Death
From his study of Italian wills Cohn concludes that the second epidemic of the Plague (1362) marked the real break with traditional views of piety and family

container-title: Only survey in English of the Plague’s impact on universities
title: The Effects of the Black Death on English Higher Education
The Black Death and Pastoral Leadership: The Diocese of Hereford in the Fourteenth Century

Studies the resilience of the English Church and its leadership through initial and subsequent outbreaks of the Plague, and concludes that the negative impact of the Plague on the workings and integrity of the institution in Hereford was manageable
Wives and Widows after the Black Death: Women in Sussex, 1350–1535
Goes against the current in painting a negative picture of women’s positions—legal, social, and economic—in the post-1348 world
English Law in the Age of the Black Death, 1348–1381: A Transformation of Governance and Law

Study of how the Black Death led to an increase in English state power through the Crown’s alliance with the Church and upper nobility and the rising gentry class and use of royal statute to stabilize the lower social classes
Crisis and Culture in Renaissance Europe

Links falling land prices to greater concentration of wealth in the hands of European upper classes and ties this to the emergence of lay cultural flourishing of the Renaissance in Florence and England

note: based on published documents dating from 1348 to 1384.
title: The Black Death in Aragon, 1348–1351
Brief study of the effects of the Plague on Aragonese royal and local administration and economy

container-title: The Black Death: The Impact of the Fourteenthcentury Plague

Discusses the Russian practice of communal construction of chapels in a single day during Plague times. Jewish Massacres and the Flagellant Movement Cohn, Norman. The Pursuit of the Millenium: Revolutionary Millenarians and Mystical Anarchists of the Middle Ages
Journal of the Rocky Mountain Medieval and Renaissance Association
publisher: Medieval and Renaissance Texts and Studies
title: Violence and the Plague in Aragon, 1348–1351
Emphasizes the social problems, especially criminality, unleashed by the destruction of the administrative and judicial structures in Aragon
Ships, Fogs, and Traveling Pairs: Plague Legend Migration in Scandinavia
Studies the most common ways that Scandinavian folk explained the spread of the Plague in the fourteenth and fifteenth centuries
Pestilence and Middle English Literature: Friar John Grimestone’s Poems on Death
Study of the role of human moral failure in bringing about the Black Death as expressed by this late-fourteenth-century English poet
The One-day Votive Church: A Religious Response to the Black Death in Early Russia
Strongly links mid-fourteenth-century flagellants to previous and similar movements, and to anti-ecclesiastical radicalism and anti-Semitism

container-title: Views events of 1348–50 in terms of both historical precedents and impacts on future development of Jewish communities
title: The Jews of Europe after the Black Death
Traces roots of European anti-Semitism from early Christianity and its effects on Jewish life up to about 1900

container-title: Change in Medieval Society: Europe North of the Alps, 1050–1500
title: The Controversy over the Alleged Sowers of the Black Death in the Contemporary Treatises on Plague
Heavily abridged version of the French original outlines case made against and for Jews poisoning wells

container-title: Journal of Medieval and Renaissance Studies
note: Explores later stages of flagellant movement for harsh anticlericalism, anti-Semitism, and other reasons why the authorities repressed them.
title: Radical Tendencies in the Flagellant Movement of the Mid-Fourteenth Century

publisher: Medieval and Renaissance Texts and Studies
title: The Black Death and Western Eschatological Mentalities
also in The Black Death: The Impact of the Fourteenth-century Plague
Views European fears of the end times in a broad historical context, and sees their rise during the Black Death as a moralistic response rather than as fear of the imminent end of the world

container-title: Journal of the Rocky Mountain Medieval and Renaissance Association
note: Plague and the Arts Boeckl, Christine. Images of Plague and Pestilence: Iconography and Iconology.
title: The Grand peur of 1348–49: The Shock Wave of the Black Death in the German Southwest

Rich article links the massacres of 1348–49 to the broader context of anti-Semitism in southwestern German areas, comparing the pattern of popular violence and its spread to the Grand peur (Great fear
Provides an overview of Plague imagery from the fourteenth through seventeenth centuries in two-dimensional formats, relating it to historical events and trends and to literary sources
Some Thoughts on Orcagna and the Black Death Style

Revises Meiss’ interpretation of the impact of the Black Death on mid-fourteenth-century painting in Florence by focusing on the decoration and functions of the Strozzi Chapel in Santa Maria Novella in Florence

container-title: Social Unrest in the Late Middle Ages
publisher: Medieval and Renaissance Texts and Studies
title: ‘He hath a thousand slayn this pestilence:’ Iconography of the Plague in the Late Middle Ages
Brief but broad treatment of the evolution of Plague imagery, especially regarding the contributions of religious and scientific thought

editor.literal: edited by W. M. Ormrod and 212 Annotated Bibliography P. G. Lindley

title: The Black Death and English Art: A Debate and Some Assumptions
Rare article on English art post-1350 raises questions of relationship of quality to style shifts in art and architecture

note: Provides starting point for most later discussions of the subject.
title: Painting in Florence and Siena after the Black Death: The Arts, Religion, and Society in the Mid-fourteenth Century
Dated and controversial study of how the Black Death affected Tuscan painting, its subject and forms

note: Overview of major saints and themes.
title: Iconography of Plague Saints in Fifteenth-century Italian Painting
The Black Death and Sienese Painting: A Problem of Interpretation
Agrees with Meiss that Sienese painting style changed after 1348, but attributes this to specific changes in patronage rather than to changes in religious sentiment

note: Good overview of main theories.
title: The Disappearance of the Plague: A Continuing Puzzle
More Than a Coincidence? The Arrival of Arsenic and the Disappearance of Plague in Early Modern Europe

Argues that the availability of huge amounts of industrial arsenic in the late seventeenth century and its sudden, widespread use as a rat poison were responsible for the disappearance of the Plague in western and central Europe

note: Responding to Appleby, credits quarantining and restrictions on trade with limiting Plague spread.
title: The Disappearance of Plague: An Alternative View
The Decameron
Boccaccio’s Introduction is a powerful and indispensable source for how people felt and reacted in the earliest outbreak

container-title: Bulletin of the History of Medicine
note: Translation without notes of this Catalan Plague consilium from 1348.
title: Jacme d’Agramont: Regiment de preservacio a epidemia o pestilencia e mortaldats
Chronicles
Contains important sections on the Black Death and the flagellants in 1348–49

note: The Fasciculus Medicinae. Translated by Luke DeMaitre.
title: Annotated Bibliography Horrox
The Black Death
Excellent collection of 128 translated primary sources or excerpts, most English and most fourteenth century. Arranged topically or by type with a very useful introduction to each section
Beautifully produced English translation of the 1493 edition of the German medical textbook with original illustrations

note: Contains three documents relating to Jewish persecution in 1348–49.
title: The Jew in the Medieval World: A Source Book: 315–1791

container-title: Popular and Practical Science of Medieval England (Medieval Texts and Studies, 11
note: Mid-fifteenth-century translation of a Scandinavian medical treatise that itself was based upon the “anonymous practitioner” of Montpellier.
title: A Translation of the Canutus Plague Treatise
Companion Encyclopedia of the History of Medicine
Useful reference source with both broad articles on medical cultures (“Chinese Medicine”) and narrower ones of use to the student of the Plague

note: approaches to disease, as well as on specific diseases (e.g., “Bubonic Plague” and “Black Death”).
title: The Cambridge World History of Human Disease
Excellent reference work containing detailed articles on various cultures
Encyclopedia of Plague and Pestilence: From Ancient Times to the Present
Short entries on a wide range of topics, including specific phases of the Second Pandemic
Dictionary of the Middle Ages
Standard reference work for the medieval period

title: 60 minutes
English society of the Plague in the much broader context of English history
Black Death/Siege of Constantinople/Conquest of the Incas
75 minutes
Documentary that uses dramatizations to evoke the horror and pathos of the event. Discusses it in terms of its world historical importance

container-title: VHS. Brief coverage of Black Death in context of London’s medieval history
title: Films for the Humanities
20 minutes
History Channel Films
50 minutes. VHS. Covers history of man’s interaction with the bubonic plague to contemporary times
The Seventh Seal
Feature film by Ingmar Bergman set in post-Plague Germany: Death stalks and plays chess with a knight for the right to take him and all of his companions

container-title: VHS. Sets the Black Death and Jewish pogroms associated with it in context of religion and society of the late medieval West. INDEX
